replies.text: I would suspect the trend of cars being more complex requiring people to rely on dealership maintenance is part of it. Also coupled with new car purchases being incentivized rather than maintaining a vehicle through a reasonable lifespan. Just a thought based on anecdotal observation. The real answer is I dont know.

In my opinion, continued effects of COVID are probably the largest factor. During the height of COVID in 20202021, new car sales were heavily impacted supply chain especially semiconductor shortages greatly reduced the availability of new cars, while financiallyimpacted consumers were not in a strong buying position. The auto parts market experienced some of their best years, as more people turned to increasing repairs of their existing vehicles. As the economy and supply chains have now more thoroughly stabilizedrecovered, the availability of new cars has increased and consumers are reaching a point where they either have to replace, or are otherwise in a better financial position to opt for buying new vehicles. With more new vehicles covered by manufacturer warranties, theres less aftermarket repair parts sales. The market may be rough for these companies for the next couple of years... Considering a likely sizable portion of current and recent buyers are doing so because they have to, German carmakers mainly positioned as luxury brands in the major U.S. market may not be catching as much of the resurgence of new car demand. VW is presumably still experiencing reputation issues.

Logistics issues Raw material supply down The cars themselves are changing very quickly and nothing the auto parts makers are making for the next generation is yet being produced at scale. TLDR its a sector going through a transition.

Ive worked in this industry for five years and witnessed the period before, during, and after COVID. Before the pandemic, everything was straightforwardparts availability was nearly perfect, and 99 of outofstock items could be sourced overnight. During COVID, we began to see delays, with essential parts sometimes taking days, weeks, or even months to arrive. Basic tools like bits and wrenches became scarce, often taking months to be delivered. To cope, we started shipping incomplete toolsets and sent the missing pieces as they became available. Despite these challenges, business was strong during this time, as people had disposable income and invested in vehicle maintenance, even when it wasnt urgent. PostCOVID, we saw a sharp decline in nonessential maintenance. When faced with costly repairs, many customers opted to buy new cars, a trend accelerated by cheap vehicle leases. These leased vehicles wont hit aftermarket shops until their leases or warranties expire, typically 34 years later, reducing current workload. Inflation and higher wages further raised workshop labor rates, while increased material costs led to even fewer repairs, with customers only addressing urgent issues for vehicle inspections or to keep their cars running. Ive even read that the average tire tread depth is lower now compared to during COVID, which could be a dangerous trend. TLDR Before COVID, parts were easily accessible. During the pandemic, we saw delays, but business was good. After COVID, rising costs and cheaper leasing options led to a sharp decline in vehicle repairs, with customers focusing on only essential maintenance.
I dont think anyone buys auto parts anymore except professional shops and high skill car enthusiasts. There is virtually no casual mechanic work done in the USA compared to 2030 years ago.
Supply chain issues is the real answer

Same as other sectors. Revenues goes up, profit goes down. Competition and globalization keeping prices down and more go to CEOs and asset owners and end users get less for more. Its extremely difficult to make a quality part with quality materials and be profitable. 2020 10 Billion Revenue and .85B profit. 8.5 profit. 2023 11.25 Revenue and 45M profit 0.4 profit. So 8 of 11 Billion isnt going to you or me or the workers. Its going to asset owners and supply chain owners and CEOs.

Afaik there are two main factors at play. First is the overall bearishness regarding new car sales in general and lagging EV adoption in particular. The other aspect is a paradigm shift from reliance on complex networks of parts suppliers to simpler supply chains and streamlined manufacturing strategies. All of that against the backdrop of protectionist tendencies in trade worldwide, that hit complex supply chains particularly hard.

Online doesnt actually work that well. The reason ORLY and AZO do so well is that theyre able to keep low turning inventory local to repair shops. Sure you can wait a few days for whatever part, but theyll have it shipped to your shop in 20 minutes to a day or to your door in a day. A lot of it is heavy parts and very specific SKUs that dont move much. Sure oil filters, wiper blades, etc can be online. But those have been available in Walmart for decades without impacting the business. Its not really viable for Amazon to keep that inventory taking space in a DC. Rock Auto does okay, but again they cant break with the pro market that needs to turn bays to make money. Its more profitable to spend the extra 20 and get another car in the shop

Crypto follows a four year cycle based on Bitcoin halving dates and euphoria that happens afterward. It might be best to wait on that first and then decide about your SQ. SQ follows that same cycle. That cycle would have Bitcoin peaking next year in 2025 like it and SQ did in 2021. It doesnt have to make sense and it probably doesnt but when BTC goes up, every Joe Q. Ill admit I never thought it would go this far, but talking about crypto like it can grow 100x again means claiming the collection of the cells for sale in a functionless spreadsheet is worth as much as the entire US stock market all US housing. FOMO alone isnt going to get you there, and thats all it has ever had.

Well, clearly they have saturation. My favorite taqueria uses square too. But... Where the cashflows going to come from? A company like BYD has better electric cars for way cheaper, yet their stock sucks because theyre running a no margin product subsidized by the chinese government to dump on the world EV market. You can have both a superior and farther reaching product and still produce bad equity returns. How does square plan to up its earnings per share? Charge higher fees? The POS industry has competitors like generic mastercard and visa and unicorns like Stripe and such.

Taxable income is the end balance after deducting expenses. Its below costs like R and D etc. Gross revenue COGS Gross profit Expenses incl SGA Net Income before tax Tax net income after tax or just net income This obviously varies by jurisdiction and type of company but its the gist of it, sort of like order of operations. You can have subtotals in there too like operating income but thats usually the same as net income before tax, it just doesnt include things like interest expense. If an entity has pass through tax then there just isnt any tax on the financials. Taxable income is not on the financials usually. Its on the tax return. Its usually close to net income but can be different. On the tax return you usually start with net income and then add or deduct various adjustments to convert the financial statement IFRS US GAAP net income to USA taxable income. For example maybe some marketing expenses are included in the financials but not tax deductible so that would be added back. Your overall thesis could be right. I just wanted to correct that one part in case it has flow through consequences for your analysis.

What is their cash flow? They can have negative earning due to things like accelerated depreciation and still have excess cash flow. Also, imagine they have to pay marketing and sales expense for new customer acquisition on a customer that signs a 20 year record storage contract. Negative earnings upfront, profit down the road.

EarningsNet income for REITs isnt a really accurate indicator of profit, because they claim depreciation on their properties every quarter, even though the market value of the properties is increasing. REITs like to record depreciation and other noncash expenses as much as possible, because theyre required to pay 90 of net income out as dividends. So keeping net income low means that they can retain more capital to use to expand their assets without relying as much on debt. The metric generally used to track REIT performance and ability to pay dividends is Funds from operationsFFO. This is essentially cash flow after paying for all overhead expensesupkeep, interest, etc. Iron Mountains FFO is 4.12 per year. Their dividend is 2.88 per year, so theyre paying out about 70 of their cash flow as dividends.

This is exactly the type of stock I love to invest in: An undervalued growth stock with a unique combination of businesses that generate profits and have huge opportunities to accelerate their growth and profits in the near future and beyond. For me, one of the key stats is the forward P/E of 15.2 expected for next year. That's very low for a tech company that's growing at a good rate and generating solid profits. I expect that as interest rates decline, SQ's forward P/E will go up to at least 20 and possibly to 30 or more (it's been much higher throughout most of Block's history). If it goes to 25, we're looking at a $110 stock. Even if it only goes to 20, SQ would be around $90 a share. And if SQ beats its earnings projections, those numbers will be even higher. This seems like one of the best opportunities in the market right now. It's now my largest position, with #2 being Nio, another stock I think will soar, and Snowflake, which is going through an uncertain time in its evolution, but I think will thrive long-term.

The reason to cut half a point is because almost all signs show that it's the right thing to do, and would still leave the Fed rate much higher than both the current 10-year and 2-year rates and well above neutral during a time of moderating inflation that's pretty close to average. It also would make sense given that the Fed didn't have a meeting last month and doesn't have one next month, and they held off on a rate cut in July despite being conflicted about it. They're smart enough to recognize that a half point cut wouldn't cause any harm and might well help facilitate (in conjunction with more cuts later this year and into next year) that soft landing they're striving for. Inflation is no longer a significant risk, whereas jobs and a potential recession are now the bigger risk factors, so 1/2 point makes sense.The only reasons to go a quarter point is because that's what they've kind of indicated they would do, and because they generally like to move slowly with rate cuts unless they perceive an emergency.I'd vote for 50 basis points if I were on the Fed, and I think a majority of voting Fed members might well do the same, though it's kind of a coin flip which way it will go. If I had to predict, I'd say the Fed will cut by 50 points, which would be great for Block and many other stocks.

Can you smell what the Fed is cooking? A lot of these stocks need a break, lower rates. In other words - society needs a break from the higher credit card rates , auto loan rates, mortgage rates. That a reason for a half a point cut but theres a lot of reasons for a quarter point cut.

I've been holding my base position and then adding another 50% when it drops more than a couple points and selling those shares back when it gains those couple of points back. When it drops more than 4 points, I double the number of shares, and continue adding every 2 points that SQ declines until I'm out of money to invest. I then sell back all shares except my base shares when SQ moves higher (with a 1-3 point gain on every group of shares I buy and re-sell). This strategy works well with a stock staying in a range for a long period of time, as seems to be happening with SQ. It also protects me when SQ eventually explodes higher because I'll still have my base position. It doesn't protect me if SQ should lose 20% of its value or more, but I don't foresee that happening. I'm typically an investor more than a trader, but SQ has provided a nice opportunity for doing both simultaneously.

Does anyone on here ever root for a stock they own to go down? I'm in that situation now, as I've sold 3/4 of my SQ shares this week, much of it late today, as I like to minimize my borrowing over the weekend, so I got my margin loan down a lot. I'm hoping to buy a lot of these shares back at a lower price on Monday or Tuesday, as I'm still a believer in SQ and see more upside for the stock long-term. There are just a lot of uncertainties right now with the Middle East, the election, the Japan situation, Russia-Ukraine, labor data, a potential recession or at least or moderate downturn (economic softening), and the usual September blues, so I decided to take some money off the table and bank a profit. If this continues heading upward at a nice clip, I still have 2000 shares, but at least I'll be able to sleep at night even if there's a downturn in the share price. I was way overextended before selling shares, and margin calls are no fun even when the market's going up.Further, I could see a scenario in which SQ heads back to the low 60s or even the 50s during this more uncertain time before jumping into the 70s or 80s in the weeks and months following the election (especially if it's a smooth transition of power this time) and/or after interest rates start going down.

Analysts reaffirm their buy ratings for Square and reiterate or raise 12-month price targets that will likely range from 75-100 except for possibly a few outliers.
